precursor_details.lithiumtributylstannate: derived from tributyltin hydride and LDA

synthesis_conditions.procedure_modification: reversed the addition sequence to keep the concentration of the stannane low during the reaction
synthesis_conditions.physical_state: bench-stable liquid that solidifies to a wax at 4 88C
synthesis_conditions.stability: No decomposition detected by NMR analysis after prolonged storage at this temperature
synthesis_conditions.decomposition_test: Heating at 60 88C in THF in the presence of H2O did not lead to decomposition

additional_steps.observation: Higher temperatures (60 88C) were required for some substrates

synthesis_conditions.note: Aryl bromides provided trace amounts of the corresponding KATs

additional_steps.solvent: 1 m aq KHCO3/DMF (2:1) mixture or 1 m K2CO3 for some substrates

synthesis_conditions.note: Vinyl Iodides displayed the highest reactivity, but vinyl triflates were almost equally reactive; vinyl bromides were also suitable substrates

materials.name: amino acid derived KATs 8 h and 8 i

synthesis_conditions.procedure: Hydrogenation of the enamines in 7 h and 7 i
synthesis_conditions.note: Separation of the enantiomers by analytical HPLC on a chiral column confirmed the configurationally stable nature of KAT amino acids

synthesis_conditions.procedure: Starting from an aryl iodide, performed the Stille cross-coupling followed by iminium formation with a different secondary amine. Subsequent reaction with either a Grignard reagent or borohydride
synthesis_conditions.note: This approach highlights the power of this method for quickly accessing this exciting class of molecules
